file_content.text: Understood.
Got it.
What's with the look? Is there something behind me?
Nice armor, I know, but this staring thing's getting weird.
Now we can talk without sub-zero wind in our ears--thank you.
Not just for saving my guys. You got me out of Hoth. You have no idea how much I was starting to hate that planet.
I hope you feel welcome here.
It's not a problem.
If your shower doesn't freeze solid halfway through, I like it here already.
I found Hoth rather picturesque, actually.
You didn't enjoy the scenery?
Digging graves out there takes the bloom off, I'm afraid.
There'll be plenty of opportunities for you to repay the favor.
You'll pay me back.
That, I will. Count on it.
You know, I miss the rest of the unit already. Even Kree.
But they're going home, and that's the important thing. They've earned it.
Haven't you?
You ever think about the future?
I refuse to believe a Jedi doesn't have plans.
There must be so much forgotten lore out there, waiting to be discovered.
I'll expand my knowledge.
Whatever my future, I'd like you to be in it.
I want to stay with you.
That could be arranged.
What we have is so rare, we should make the most of it. Think about making... a real commitment to each other.
What we call "the future" is countless threads of cause and consequence, waiting to come to fruition.
The future is unknowable.
I should have learned by now...
I always try to think a few steps ahead. If you want things to turn out right, you've got to make it happen.
That's what we're fighting for. People being free to make plans, and live however they want.
Like, settling down somewhere, with their beautiful Jedi Master.
I like the sound of this.
Keep going.
Are you proposing?
You mean marriage?
Yes. I am.
I love you. I want to spend my life with you... if you'll have me.
There's nothing I'd like more.
Yes, I will.
Then... then one day we'll have a huge ceremony. On Tython. Or wherever you'd like. And invite everyone.
But for now, take my promise. I'm yours, Barsen'thor of the Jedi. Forever.
May we always cherish each other, remembering the lives we now leave behind, and joyful for the life we begin together.
And I, yours.
I hope you appreciate what's involved in a Jedi wedding....
A huge ceremony, you said?
I'll take my chances.
We have all night to whisper promises to each other.
Just kiss me.
You always know just what to say.
I need some time to think this over.
I can't answer right away.
Sorry. My fault for springing this on you.
Don't worry about it, for now. We've got all the time we need to make plans.
I'm sorry. I can't.
I have to say no.
I care for you, but... I can't. I'm sorry.
No. I can't do that.
It's because of the order, isn't it?
But I'm still here for you. And who knows? Maybe one day, things will be different.
Like, where you'd want to end up when all this is over.
The Jedi Temple will always be a home to me.
I'll return to Tython.
What about you? Are you planning to retire somewhere?
You first.
The order, and the Republic, need all the help they can get. I won't have the luxury of retirement.
Jedi never retire.
My guys on Hoth always talked about going home, but for me, "home" was some refugee camp they closed years back.
Besides, who could settle on just one world? There's always more to see.
Maybe that's my retirement. Swap the blaster for a ship, start seeing the galaxy. Assuming this Sith data in my head doesn't start leaking.
Even if it becomes a problem, I'm sure we could find a way to help you.
Don't worry about that.
I'd be concerned about this too, but you can't let it take over your life.
Be positive.
Losing a good soldier to a Sith experiment would be a real victory for the Empire.
An unfortunate prospect.
We'll figure it out, we always do. It's good to know there's someone I can always count on.
So, I was doing some thinking.
And my thinking is: This is the best posting I've ever had.
We'd never have come so far without your help.
That's due to your efforts.
So you'd say this mission has been... uniquely memorable?
[Flirt] The very best?
Absolutely.
What's at the other end of the spectrum?
And the worst?
A five-week rotation on a planetoid that smelled like sewage, but that's beside the point.
Don't rest on your laurels, there's still much to be done.
Let's keep it that way.
That's sort of where I'm going with this.
I want you to know I'm with you to the end. Win or lose.
I'd rather be your lieutenant than a Republic colonel. Doesn't matter what comes next for us, I've got your back.
I need to talk to you.
What we have... I've never felt this way about anyone.
I can't stop thinking about you. Your scent, your smile... I want you to be mine.
It's alright, Felix. I sensed your feelings long before. And returned them.
I know, and I feel the same.
I love you, more than anything.
I've waited to hear that.
You're everything I want.
We don't need words to express how we feel.
Shh. I know.
You want to stop me saying "I love you," you'll have to do better than that.
I got a letter from Milo Pellam. Kind of rambling, but still, sounds like he's getting better.
Thing is, this letter has "intel" about the facility where we were held. He wants me to give the intel to SIS, but it's... you couldn't call it coherent.
Coherent or not, Milo could have useful information. I'm sure SIS would be interested.
Give it to them anyway.
Fair enough. Milo's trying to be a soldier again, I should treat him like one.
Start a dialogue with Milo. Ask him questions about the facility, see if he's consistent. Then decide.
Write back. It might help him.
Seems smart. Hey, it might even help him focus. I'll get to work on a reply.
I wouldn't bother, then.
I was thinking the same, I'm not sure this is worth bothering SIS with. Maybe when Milo's better.
It's encouraging that he's able to write at all. Maybe there's hope for me too.
This must be torture for you, huh?
A library of ancient knowledge in my head, and no way to reach it without me going crazy.
The teachings of madmen, murderers or cantankerous old ghosts have little appeal for me.
I don't need Sith knowledge.
So nothing you're planning to rummage for. Good to know.
Felix, we don't know what the holocron's knowledge could do to you.
I'm worried for you.
Hey, hey. It's alright. Nothing's changed, okay?
This isn't funny.
Be serious.
A ground-pounding soldier getting the wisdom of the ages? Come on, that's a little funny.
Think of what I could learn from a holocron belonging to the Dark Council itself.
Yes, it's infuriating.
Hey, don't get any ideas, this is the only brain I've got.
I won't pretend I like this. It's a massive risk for both of us. But, I've carried this data for years and never knew a thing.
And, I have you. If anyone could keep me from madness, it's you.
Thank you for having such faith in me.
That means a lot.
I trust you with my life.
Whatever's ahead, I love you, and we can work through it.
I love you.
I love you, too.
If you did become unhinged, would I really notice the difference?
Ha, you're crazy already.
I thought--well, that's the spirit. I guess.
However this turns out, I'm still yours. I swear.
Besides, if anything does go wrong, I have your expertise on hand.
I'm always here if you need me.
Of course.
I'm afraid we're in uncharted territory here, Lieutenant.
Nobody's an expert on this.
It's probably best if the others don't know about your condition.
It should be our secret.
Right. Tharan might suddenly decide he's a brain surgeon and "help."
I doubt Republic Command will have a change of heart if I report this. My career's still going nowhere.
But... so what? You have a cause worth fighting for. I want to see it through.
You're not gonna believe this. Remember Milo's talk about a "glowing box"? And the lady doctor he was chasing?
That "lady doctor" turns out to be real. She sent me a message.
Lieutenant Iresso, my name is Doctor Sera Fray. I hear you've been looking for me.
I have fled the Empire; your search has put me in grave danger. But I imagine you won't be satisfied until you have answers.
I am responsible for Milo Pellam's... instability. And your suffering. I could not refuse a Darth's orders.
It sounds like the Sith are involved in this.
A Darth's orders?
No dissembling, I see.
At least she admits it.
Those who do evil have a thousand excuses. Those who do what's right need none.
A feeble defense.
The Sith Lord I... once served, Darth Ouzal, is a great scholar. He even advises the Dark Council. His specialty is ancient holocrons.
What's a holocron?
It's short for "holographic chronicle." Both the Jedi and the Sith use them to store ancient knowledge.
They store information.
Holocrons contain ancient knowledge. To the untrained eye, they match Milo's description.
A "glowing box."
Artifacts containing knowledge and rituals. Sith holocrons have been the downfall of many unwary Jedi.
A dangerous relic.
The Dark Council trusted Darth Ouzal to decipher a rare holocron for them. But, Ouzal saw a chance to keep its knowledge for himself.
He wanted to copy the holocron into a person's mind.
The matrix of a holocron is far too complex to be mapped onto a person's brain.
I thought that was impossible.
I think I see where this is leading.
So that's what was done.
The ingenuity of the Sith never ceases to amaze me.
Unethical, but impressive.
Darth Ouzal requisitioned two prisoners from the Empire. You, Lieutenant Iresso, and your friend.
The initial procedure was... imperfect. Milo Pellam's mind simply collapsed under so much knowledge. But you were a great success.
A great success? She hid a Sith library in my head!
Doctor Fray must have sealed the holocron's data from your conscious mind, somehow.
And, you didn't go insane.
The recording hasn't finished.
Let's keep listening.
You possess more Sith knowledge than a graduate of their Academy. Ironic.
You outsmart our enemy.
Any Sith would kill for that holocron's knowledge. But no one will know it's there, unless you tell them.
All I have said is the truth. Now, please, remove my image from the Republic database. I won't be safe until then.
Lieutenant--Felix. That's your name, isn't it? I'm... I'm sorry.
She's asking me to keep her safe? At least she's got a blasted sense of humor.
She obviously regrets her actions. Show the compassion she couldn't, and help her.
You should remove her picture.
You're way more forgiving than I am. Okay, I'll see it gone.
Doctor Fray's lucky I've got a Jedi to be my conscience. Okay, I'll see it gone.
What will you do?
Doctor Fray broke Milo's mind and ruined your life. Let her fend for herself.
Leave her picture where it is.
Right. I'm not helping an Imperial fugitive. Not after she...
I need to think. 'Scuse me.
That's quite the fighting style you have.
Looks like you sneaked a few combat manuals in amongst the history texts.
There is poetry and logic in battle.
I embrace all learning.
Some things cannot be taught, only improved.
No, it's a natural talent.
I can't help the Republic if I can't protect myself.
A Jedi must know defense.
I'm used to fighting in squads. Constant redeployment's taught me to sync fast with whoever's at my shoulder.
Now you--you know your tactics, but you're not afraid of your gut instinct either.
I've tightened down my style to match. Might make the Imperials think twice the next time we're cornered.
Hey.
I have a surprise for you. Four hours, thirty-four minutes and eleven seconds.
And to what do I owe this surprise?
What's the occasion?
No reason.
All right, you have me hooked.
Go on....
You may be misunderstanding the concepts at work here.
I'm confused, not surprised.
Let this be a practice, then. I'll eventually get the hang of it.
I thought you could use some R & R, so I arranged a little circuitry fault in the ship's doors.
You'll have about four hours of peace and quiet in your quarters. Time to read, or meditate, or... whatever you like.
I think we should take this time for ourselves.
Then come with me.
Good choice.
You wouldn't leave me with just my studies for company, would you?
But I'd be lonely....
I'd never want you to feel lonely.
How thoughtful of you. There's a copy of the Vordegen Codex I've been sorely neglecting.
Finally, study time!
I did have a few... strategies to help you unwind. If you're interested.
I'm not a fool. I just wanted to be certain of your meaning.
I am, I was teasing.
You got my attention, that's for sure.
Actions speak louder than words.
Show me.
Maybe I won't use words at all next time.
You're so beautiful.
All that emotional control. It was just--waiting for the right moment.
I'm glad I was here for it.
Thank you, for my surprise vacation.
I like your surprises.
You're very welcome.
Better stay on your guard, though. The next ambush might be right around the corner.
Sometimes those "right moments" can arrive in quick succession.
Who says it's over?
Hold that thought. Just for now.
Give me a chance to surprise you all over again.
Fun's fun, but we have business to attend to.
Well, duty calls.
Just "fun," huh. Roger that.
Don't worry. If I finish the codex, I have the writings of Master Q'Anilia, and a volume of Khilese poetry.
No, reading will suit me fine.
Ha. Okay, okay. Go on, enjoy yourself. I'll... be around.
I've been meaning to ask. Have you been in any major battles? Apart from Hoth, I mean.
A Jedi's role is less about being on the front lines, and more about stopping the battle before it starts.
Jedi aren't soldiers.
When the Republic has needed my help, I've always been ready.
I've seen my share.
My battles have mostly been behind the scenes, with enemies few would recognize.
Not ones you'd know about.
Standard for a Jedi, I guess.
My postings haven't exactly been stellar, but I was there for the Eight Hour Invasion. Did my part, watched the Imperials slink away.
I'm proud of that. Though what we're doing seems more important. Even if the historians never know.
Still no luck with the doctor's picture. I think it's time to admit defeat.
You must be the judge of that.
If you think it best.
You said yourself, this may be your best lead.
Are you sure?
Admitting defeat isn't becoming of a Republic soldier.
You're giving up.
I won't give up looking for her, but I don't want to turn into Milo, either.
Her picture's in the Republic database. So I'm going to delete my copy. I've done all I can.
Sorry I haven't been giving you the attention you deserve.
Are we okay?
Don't give it another thought.
Of course we are.
You're sweet when you're worried.
How could I resist that look?
Careful. Give away your weaknesses, and who knows what might happen.
As long as this doesn't happen again.
I suppose so.
I guess that's the best I can hope for.
I have a good situation here. I won't let the past mess it up.
Any chance I can use the ship's long-distance communication system, for about an hour?
Is there somebody you're trying to reach?
Looking for someone?
Sort of.
The ship is your home too, feel free.
Of course.
Great! Thanks.
Be sure you don't interrupt any important communications.
If no one else is using it.
Don't worry, any calls from the Council will kick me off.
I want to put Milo's "lady doctor" into the Republic's database. I keep studying her picture, but... nothing.
I'm hoping it can jog something about her or that "glowing box." I'm close--practically seeing her in my sleep.
Take care that you don't become obsessed with this woman.
That's not healthy.
I'm not obsessed. This is important. What if I just need one more day before I remember?
Listen to yourself. You're losing perspective.
You just proved my point.
If you've tried this hard already, one more day won't make a difference.
It might be time to move on.
So I should just give up?
Given how little we know of what happened, this approach might bear fruit. Eventually.
Perhaps you're right.
I hoped I had pride of place in your dreams.
Her, but not me?
Hold on. Are you jealous?
Jealousy is a base emotion. I'm concerned about you.
No, I'm worried.
Why? I'm trying to get some answers.
I think you need to get some perspective on this.
Don't be ridiculous.
You don't understand.
You could be a bit more attentive, that's all.
Maybe a little.
Getting captured ruined Milo's life, and destroyed my career. I'll never be anything more than a lieutenant. I deserve to know why.
I know you're looking out for me, but imagine how you'd feel. I can't miss this chance.
Has her face triggered anything?
Is it working?
No. Everything between Althir and waking up in that cell is still a big fat blank.
You said she seems familiar. Don't give up now.
Keep trying, you'll get there.
Right. Thanks for understanding.
I owe it to Milo to find her.
I'll let you know if anything comes back to me.
I got Milo off Tatooine okay. But--heck, I don't even know where to start.
Milo was trying to talk to me, but he couldn't get the words out. He kept using other languages. Equations, even. Like his mind was shattered.
Does he know what the Imperials did while you were held prisoner?
What happened to him?
That's terrible. Poor Milo.
Regrettably, I have experience in this area.
Madness. Sounds familiar.
I tried asking him about when we were captured, if he knew anything.
If I understood him right, Milo said a doctor came into his cell. She showed him a "glowing box". That's when it all went wrong inside his head.
Thing is... Milo said this doctor used that box on me, too.
The doctor, this "box" she had--none of it seems familiar?
You don't remember?
Nope, and I'm guessing that box is the reason why.
This is troubling.
And you didn't see Milo. How d'you think I feel?
With respect, Milo is hardly a reliable witness.
Don't trust a madman's word.
You trust a man with your life, you learn to read him. He thought he was telling the truth.
So, Milo's lady doctor used a glowing box on both of us. I lose seven days of memory, and Milo loses his mind.
A glowing box. Maybe a new Imperial torture device.
There are ancient relics that fit that description, too.
Or it could be an artifact.
You're the expert. But me and Milo were nobodies. Why use an artifact on us?
If it was experimental, that may explain why it had such drastically different effects on you and Milo.
An experiment? That fits.
But unless we find one and take it apart, there's no way to be sure.
It might not be important. The woman who did this to you and Milo; she's the one we need to find.
That doctor is the key.
I think Milo tracked the doctor to Tatooine. He thought the starship he blew up was hers.
He gave me a picture. Assuming it's actually her, that might give us a lead. I'll see what I can find out.
I got word from Tatooine.
Six holocalls, a few payments to the right people, and Milo's a free man.
All I need to do is meet him and his security escort at Anchorhead. But Milo's still in a bad way.
So his time in isolation didn't help.
I'm sorry to hear that.
He's getting worse. They had to sedate him.
We shouldn't keep him waiting.
Then let's go together.
I appreciate it, but I should probably take this one. If Milo's really this unstable, too many people might scare him.
Be aware, I have enough passengers to handle without taking on a charity case.
I'm not bringing him aboard.
Then it's a good thing I made arrangements already.
I'll take a shuttle to Tatooine and see Milo gets somewhere safe. Shouldn't risk him hurting himself, or blowing up someone else's starship.
Thinking he was dead... it was almost easier than this.
Milo could know what happened to you when you were captured.
Still, he may have answers.
Attros Finn, a Jedi researcher on Coruscant, once treated my Master. His experience may be useful.
Jedi treatment might help.
It's worth a shot.
If the man who lost his ship is still around, he may want revenge. Don't give him an opening.
Watch your back.
I hear that.
Don't worry, I'll make sure I'm ready for trouble before I move out. See you soon.
Remember I told you about Milo Pellam? Who vanished when we were captured by the Empire?
After we talked, I put his name out, in case he had a wife or kids he hadn't mentioned.
Instead, I find out he was arrested on Tatooine a few weeks ago. He actually made it!
I didn't think Tatooine had any laws to break.
Arrested for what?
I'm glad he's alright.
I can't believe he's alive. But....
He may have escaped the Empire, but it appears his situation is little improved.
And... now he's in prison.
Milo's being held for "destruction of private property."
Anchorhead authorities said he's been acting nutty since he was arrested. They had to isolate him.
Milo was a rock. Something's wrong.
Perhaps he was badly treated when the Empire captured him.
He may have been tortured.
I have to see him myself.
If we spoke to him, there might be something I could do.
Can we help him?
You read my mind again.
Took the question right out of my mouth.
Tatooine's authorities are hardly reliable. They may have the wrong person.
Mistaken identity, perhaps.
No, the picture they sent is definitely him.
I can get him out, but there's a hitch. The property Milo destroyed was a starship.
Owner's a gangster, and he's a little upset. So the authorities aren't too happy about setting Milo free.
Gangsters tend to spread their anger around.
In case of a gang war.
Exactly.
He'll have all the protection he needs once we arrive.
He'll be safe with us.
You may need to accept that Milo's changed, and that he belongs behind bars.
Prison might be best for him.
I can't abandon him, not if there's anything I can do.
I wrote up a signed character reference for Milo.
Could you sign it, too? A Jedi Master's endorsement would really speed things along.
This situation's precarious enough. We should go by the book.
No. Let's do this right.
It's my duty to help anyone who's been unjustly imprisoned.
Of course I'll sign it.
Thank you. This means a lot.
I'll send it to Tatooine, along with Milo's bail.
Sorry, I can't vouch for a man I've never met.
But I don't know Milo.
That makes sense. Milo's release should be ironclad. I'll have a quiet word with the authorities.
All these years I thought he was dead. What happened to him out there?
I've been thinking.
If we take this any further--the Jedi Council's going to find out.
Jedi aren't supposed to get involved, right? Will you get a reprimand?
If the Jedi is trustworthy and shows good judgment, the Council tends to be lenient.
Relationships are tolerated.
Not a ringing endorsement, but better than I thought.
I think this is worth taking the chance, if you agree.
I'll risk it if you will.
Discretion, valor, better part of. Got it.
Jedi are usually disciplined for having relationships, if they get caught.
It's more than likely.
We could stop, if you want. Go back to the way things were.
I can't see you as just "Lieutenant Iresso" anymore.
I don't think I can.
I don't care what the Council thinks.
Not a chance.
Okay. If we're discreet, maybe we'll escape with a four-hour lecture.
Jedi decisions are kind of a mystery to me. For a while, I couldn't understand why you let Valon go.
I saw your face when he went free. I hated doing that to you.
I'm sorry.
That's command sometimes; you swallow your medicine.
You have to leave Hoth eventually, Felix.
You're still dwelling on that?
That decision was about what was best for the Republic.
It wasn't about you.
No, I get why you recruited him. I just really hate the guy.
I know a part of you will always belong to the Republic.
But the rest of you is safe with me.
That's what people always focus on about the Jedi. Being alone.
Truth is, I don't know much about the Jedi. But I'd like to.
Wherever we go, we know the Force is living and growing all around us. It gives you a great appreciation for life.
We see connections everywhere.
You sound so... I wish I could see what you see.
Studying the Force takes discipline and vigilance. We have to be selfless. Sometimes it's hard.
We make many sacrifices.
Come on. You need to be selfish every now and then.
We face challenges few can comprehend, but the rewards are greater than a lifetime of living safely.
A risky life, but worthwhile.
Risk, and reward. A little like what we're doing right now.
Don't give up your secrets all at once. I want to find some out for myself.
Considering the repercussions, that might be best.
Yes, perhaps we should.
Okay. Then one kiss will have to be enough.
The Republic's holding up, but we're still taking a real beating against the Empire.
I'm in this to win. No question of that. But d'you ever wonder what would happen if we lost?
We've suffered defeats and setbacks before, and always survived to rebuild.
The Republic will prevail.
Makes you wonder; just what do we have that the Empire doesn't?
Slavery, fear, living at the whim of some Imperial overseer... not a prospect I want to dwell on.
I try not to.
Me neither. But you know me, like to think ahead.
Command will have some kind of contingency plan. If the time comes to use it, I hope we're leading the charge.
Thinking like that is defeatist. If you're here to win, do it.
No, and neither should you.
If you never plan for a defeat, you stay defeated when it happens.
Just wanted some input. Forget I asked.
Uh, can we talk for a minute?
There's something I think you should know about me.
You don't need to tell me anything you don't want to.
That's not necessary.
I know. But I'd like to be straight with you.
I'd like to know everything about you.
[Flirt] How fascinating.
I'd better start here, then.
Go ahead.
You once dressed up as a Hutt to get an insanity discharge?
Wait, let me guess.
Glorious mental images aside, this is kind of important.
A few years ago, I was captured by the Empire. I was scouting on Althir with my friend Milo, and we ran into an Imperial strike team.
I woke up in an Imperial cell with a headache.
I remember Private Kree saying something about you being captured.
Your men mentioned this.
Yeah. Once he found out, he never got tired of needling me about it.
Was Milo with you?
What about your friend?
There was no sign of him.
Better to die than risk capture and interrogation.
You should have fought back.
We tried, but two against a dozen isn't good odds.
When I managed to escape and reach a Republic ship, I realized I'd lost time. Seven days. Whatever happened to me is still a blank.
There are Jedi techniques to recall lost or repressed memories.
I could help you remember.
They tried, but all I got was... stuff I've tried to forget.
What do you think happened to you?
Any theories?
I have no idea. Nothing I come up with fits all the facts.
Medically I'm fine, but my commanders don't like it. So I get shuffled around, wherever they need an extra blaster.
That's why I keep being reassigned. I just thought you should know.
I appreciate knowing this.
Thank you for telling me.
Better you hear it from me than someone else.
So your career has stalled, and you have to live with those lost days.
This must be difficult.
I got captured by the Empire and survived. Thousands don't.
I hope you'll understand if I keep a close eye on you.
I'll be watching you.
As you wish. But I'm no danger to anyone, especially you.
Okay. But it's not necessary.
So you're a liability to the Republic and everyone you serve with.
This makes you a risk.
Someday I'll find a commander who gives me the benefit of the doubt. I was just trying to keep you apprised.
You know what bothers me most? Milo Pellam, the guy who was with me on Althir, got captured too. But no one ever saw him again.
I guess I was the lucky one.
I was hoping you'd have time for a quick strategy session.
I was running a few scenarios--repelling a boarding party, what if someone gets captured, stuff like that.
I was wondering what your... preferred tactics are.
Time and patience usually reveal a weakness to exploit.
A careful study of the foe.
So, what if patience won't cut it?
Why waste time, Lieutenant? Better to strike to the heart of the matter.
[Flirt] Being direct.
There is another scenario I haven't solved yet.
Say a soldier found himself... captivated, by a superior force. What should he do?
If he truly wanted the upper hand, he would have to exploit any chance he was given.
Attack.
Ascertain the intentions of the other party, and adjust his disposition to match.
Defend.
He'd have to give in to the inevitable, and hope for mercy.
Surrender.
I... you know what? It was pretty disrespectful of me to say that.
I'm sorry. I keep forgetting you're a Jedi Master.
A female Jedi Master, who has thoughts and feelings that have nothing to do with the Force.
And a woman.
Can't you put that aside, and be honest?
Then forget, and talk to me.
I don't know if I can say it right.
Too late. You already have my undivided attention.
Don't back down now.
I thought, maybe I felt this way because I was still dealing with Hoth. But Hoth's over, and that feeling's still here.
I look at you, and it's like I can see the places you've been, the mark you've left. I want to know more.
It's not right to see a Jedi that way, but I do.
The Force binds all things. Does acknowledging that bond make it evil?
Why is it wrong?
Well. Let's see.
Something new for you to meditate on.
Then try closing your eyes.
Easily solved. [Kiss him.]
You know how to make a point.
I'll be seeing things differently from now on.
I am flattered, but we can't afford to be selfish. Too many people depend on us.
We should stop this, here.
You make a lot of sense. As always.
We still make a world-class team. Let's put this behind us and move on, okay?
Tactics are less important than destroying the enemy and accomplishing your goal.
Enough stupid games.
Okay. I guess it wasn't as important as I thought.
I have to ask. What do you want us to do if you're taken by the Empire?
Get yourselves to safety, and send word to Tython. The Jedi have emergency procedures in place.
Notify the Jedi Council.
I bet they've had to use them, too. Okay, I'll log the order.
I'm sure I could rely on my friends to bring me home.
I'd hope to be rescued.
Heh, no problem; I'd break an arm if I tried to stop Qyzen going after you.
I'm far more valuable to the Empire dead. If I'm captured, assume the worst.
Alive? That won't happen.
Cheery, aren't you? Okay, if those are your orders, I'll make sure they're logged.
Not a pleasant topic, I know. But it never hurts to plan in advance.
Good news. One of my guys from Hoth got a promotion. Private Lavik made it to specialist.
Please send him my congratulations.
Good for him.
Thanks, I'll let him know.
Regrettably, there was little time on Hoth for introductions.
Who was he?
He was one of our runners, a Twi'lek. Good guy.
You had my attention and lost it, Lieutenant.
I had hoped for better news.
Okay, but Lavik deserves someone getting excited.
He's gone to Ord Mantell for training. I was there right after my transfer from... Felucia? No, Dantooine.
Ord Mantell. That posting was lousy.
I imagine it seems rather trivial since facing Captain Valon.
Surely not worse than Hoth.
Hoth was a bad mission in good company; this was the other way around.
I was in a unit scattering a separatist training camp. Setting noise charges, ambushes, that sort of thing.
What were you doing there?
How so?
We'd discovered a separatist training camp--me and another lieutenant were trying to break it up.
But Lieutenant Jorgan had seniority, and he let me know it. Snap inspections, status reports... every day he was up in arms about something.
Discipline is the shield of both a soldier and a Jedi.
Sometimes that's necessary.
I guess that's true.
Did you get used to it eventually?
How did you cope with him?
I said "Yes, sir" when he ranted, then did what was best for the unit.
Maybe I'm being too hard on Jorgan. He was a good soldier. He's probably a general by now.
Perhaps you gave Jorgan good reason to keep rebuking you.
Sounds like you were sloppy.
I did right by my unit. It wasn't status reports or drills that kept them alive.
I think Jorgan knew that. He was a jerk, but there was a good soldier underneath.
We did the job and didn't lose a single man. Jorgan got a commendation. I got transferred to Serroco, then to Duro, then Hoth.
It sounds like you're constantly being reassigned. Is that normal?
Why so many transfers?
Army life isn't easy.
If it had been up to me, you'd have been properly compensated for your efforts.
[Flirt] I'd have rewarded you.
With you in charge, I'd have been too distracted to earn any reward.
Glad I'm not being transferred this time. I hope.
If you shared responsibility with Jorgan, you should have been recognized for your achievement.
You weren't commended?
Thanks, but I don't get commendations. I get a "well done" written on the back of my transfer orders.
And everyone lived long and wisely afterwards?
So, a happy ending for all.
Apart from the separatists. Plus I got a brand new scar on Serroco.
I hope Private--sorry, Specialist Lavik--appreciates what he's got.
Thank you, but war stories have little appeal for me.
I'm really not interested.
Sure, didn't mean to bore you. Back to work.
You know, I did some numbers. This could wind up being the longest assignment I've had in three years.
Scary how time flies when your mind's on other things.
Your mood does seem much brighter.
I'm glad you're happy.
I have my reasons.
Being around a fetching hologram must be distracting indeed.
[Flirt] Oh, you mean Holiday.
Uh, women I can literally see through don't do a lot for me.
Meantime, I was hoping to get better acquainted with... the ship. It's got a lot of potential. A little mystery, too. I'm curious.
If you're going to indulge your curiosity, perhaps I'll do the same.
[Flirt] I like mysteries, too.
Who knows? We might even meet in the middle.
Let me know if your investigations get anywhere.
[Flirt] Sounds intriguing.
I'm sure you'll know before I do.
Time might end up flying faster than I thought.
All Padawans know curiosity can lead to disaster.
I'm not comfortable with this.
Then I'll trust your judgment, and admire the ship for what it is.
If you're distracted from your duties, Lieutenant, I trust you'll remedy the situation.
If that's all, I should go.
Roger that.
Still feel fresh, though. On Hoth, all I could think about was shore leave. Somewhere sunny, or maybe going a little crazy on Nar Shaddaa....
Where would you go on leave, if you had the time?
Jedi don't take "leave"; we have too many responsibilities.
I can't, I'm always on duty.
Hedonism can be liberating, and Nar Shaddaa is overflowing with it.
Nar Shaddaa is fun....
I'm not sure even Nar Shaddaa could handle a Jedi who wants to feel "liberated."
At least you can see there's life beyond duty. I'll keep that in mind.
We have a vital mission. I don't want to turn around and find out you've wandered off on vacation.
Just focus on the job.
I know, I know, you need all hands on deck.
Still, there's more to life than work, even for Jedi.
Your friend Qyzen's something else. He was asking how many kills I've made.
In Trandoshan society, an individual's status is determined by hunting.
It's part of his culture.
Oh. Wonder what your status is if you say "I don't keep count."
What did you tell him?
So, how many, Lieutenant?
I don't keep count. He seemed a bit offended by that.
It's a Trandoshan thing; it doesn't really matter what you say.
Just ignore him.
He's odd company for a Jedi Master.
I've been posted all over, but I haven't met many Trandoshans. Or Jedi.
I always think of Jedi Masters as being stationed on Tython. And being... well, you're more hands-on than I expected.
The Force can't dig a garden or build a city's defenses. Sometimes you must get your hands dirty.
One must work to succeed.
I hear that.
Do you object to someone adding a personal touch, Lieutenant?
[Flirt] Is that a bad thing?
If you find that more satisfying, who am I to argue with a Jedi?
Did you think I would stand back and reason our opponents to death?
What were you expecting, then?
Not sure, but I'd pay good credits to see that.
At least your missions aren't as hair-raising as mine were. It's been years since I slept through the night without some crisis coming up.
I'd rather be protecting the galaxy than be shackled to the Jedi Temple.
Tython's dull.
Absolutely. Safe gets dull.
Don't get me wrong, it's nice to not have blaster shots parting my hair. And I haven't had a billet this good in... oh. Years.
Trandoshans, Jedi, it's all good. I'm glad to be here.
Can I have a word, when we're back at the ship?
When you're free, can I talk to you?
Hey there.
Okay, I've caught my breath. Ready to go?
Don't push your luck.
Hey.
Roger that.
Glad we're on the same page. So, what do I do?
